did.unittitle: ILR School Audio-Visual Department Video Cassette Collection, 1955- 2008
did.origination:
New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations (NYSSILR);
Audio- Visual Department
did.repository: Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: The ILR School Audio-Visual Department Video Cassette Collection consists of video recordings of various ILR faculty and related people. Some of those included are as follows: Tom Juravich with Labor Songs; Seymour Lipset; an interview with Jimmy Hoffa; J. Sheinkman; ILR Alumni; Sam Bachrach; Lois Gray; George Brooks; Alice Cook; ILR School Anniversary interviews and Jean McKelvey; Milton Konvitz, Maurice Neufeld as well as some conferences and events.

controlaccess.corpname: New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations.
New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations. Audio-Visual Dept.

accessrestrict.p: Access to the collections in the Kheel Center is restricted. Please contact a reference archivist for access to these materials.

userestrict.p: This collection must be used in keeping with the Kheel Center Information Sheet and Procedures for Document Use.

prefercite.p: ILR School Audio-Visual Department Video Cassette Collection #/4191 AV. Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library.

scopecontent.p: James Riddle (Jimmy) Hoffa was interviewed at Cornell Universityâs ILR School in April 1975, only 3 months before he disappeared. Hoffa was on campus for a series of meetings and lectures and, according to Professor Cletus Daniel, Hoffa was asked for a filmed interview early that morning but he declined. Throughout the dayâs meetings and discussions, Daniel continued to talk with Hoffa. During lunch, Daniel told Hoffa that he had been a Teamster, and showed Hoffa his separation card. Seeing that, Hoffa felt more comfortable with the idea of an interview and agreed to it. Because the interview was arranged at the last minute, the best video recording equipment was already in use. As a result, the sound and visual tracks on the original video recording are poor quality.
Interview of Jimmy Hoffa with Cletus Daniel, Roger R. Keeran, James O. Morris, Robert F. Risley, and Robert R. Julian.
